awd_titl_txt: FMSG: Cyber: Federated Deep Learning for Future Ubiquitous Distributed Additive Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
Distributed additive manufacturing has promising potential to connect and coordinate individual manufacturers for efficient, on-demand production. It can leverage the freeform fabrication of numerous additive manufacturers to form a flexible and robust supply chain and achieve reconfigurable mass customization in the future. However, product quality, consistency and privacy concerns among those distributed manufacturers pose a grand challenge to fully unleashing the potential of distributed additive manufacturing. This Future Manufacturing Seed Grant (FMSG) CyberManufacturing project will support fundamental research to provide needed knowledge for developing a unified algorithmic and training framework. The new framework, named FEDMDL, will lay a solid foundation to enable consistent and reliable production in a privacy-preserving, insight-sharing manufacturing network. This will further promote the adoption of additively manufactured parts in various industries, such as aerospace, automobile, healthcare, and will boost the participation of small-and-medium-sized manufacturers in the national supply chain. Therefore, results from this research will benefit the competitive advantages of US manufacturing and economy. This research provides manufacturing companies with the synergy of novel machine learning and federated computing techniques. The multi-disciplinary approach will help broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in research and positively impact engineering education. 
 
The unified algorithmic and training framework, FEDMDL, will chart a new theoretical path to enabling reliable production, consistent quality, and privacy-preserving data sharing in distributed additive manufacturing. FEDMDL will synthesize the fundamental physics of additive manufacturing processes into deep learning algorithms and train the new models on a federated learning cyberinfrastructure. In this seed grant, FEDMDL will be prototyped with fatigue performance assessment of additively manufactured metals in a distributed manufacturing network. The research team will: (1) conduct fatigue testing and defect characterization to understand material-defect-geometry-loading-fatigue relationships; (2) develop fracture-mechanics-centric deep learning models to approximate multi-physics multiscale processes and predict the fatigue performance of complex geometries under multiaxial loading; (3) design a cross-silo, additive-manufacturing-aware federated learning cyberinfrastructure to train the deep learning models with collective insights from the sparse, siloed datasets across manufacturers; and (4) evaluate the framework by deploying it in a real-world distributed additive manufacturing network. This work will result in an experimentally validated, generalizable algorithmic and training framework to catalyze research and applications in quality modeling, qualification, and control for future distributed additive manufacturing with collective intelligence.

This project is jointly funded by the Division of Civil. Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation, the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), and the Division of Electrical, Communications, and Cyber Systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This novel interdisciplinary project investigated fundamental knowledge and developed a generalizable methodology, named FedMDL, for privacy preserving and insight sharing among different manufacturers in a future distributed manufacturing network for continuous production improvement. For manufacturers adopting new technologies (such as the Industrial Internet of Things, advanced sensing, and machine learning) for data collection and analysis, they can benefit from the trustworthy information sharing of collective insights for their production. We used laser powder bed fusion (L-PBF), an additive manufacturing process, as the subject to investigate the generalizable methodology due to its unprecedented manufacturing capability for any complex geometry and its on-demand customization to form a flexible supply chain. In particular, we used L-PBF process variability among different machines (e.g., EOS M290 and Renishaw AM250) and investigated their defect formation and resultant fatigue behaviors to prototype a distributed manufacturing for developing FedMDL.  

In FedMDL, we have discovered the needed knowledge of L-PBF for modeling fatigue life from defects, developed two novel machine learning models for accurately modeling fatigue life from limited data, created a novel federated learning method for insights sharing from heterogeneous data, and investigated different federated learning techniques to more effectively tackle the resource and data heterogeneity at scale. FedMDL has laid a solid technological foundation for future distributed manufacturing and enabled privacy preserving and insight sharing for continuous production improvement. Six papers are so far published in journals and conference proceedings, and eleven presentations are given at different conferences to disseminate the project outcomes. These methods and frameworks in FedMDL can be easily extended to other applications, such as different materials, another additive manufacturing process, or even subtractive manufacturing for machine learning modeling with privacy preserving and insight sharing.

The new findings of the fundamental knowledge of L-PBF are obtained from manufacturing, material characterization, fatigue testing and data analysis based on a comprehensive design of experiments. It is found that the fracture failure of L-PBF specimens in machined surface conditions can be attributed to critical internal defects. Thus, optimizing the process parameters to control the size and number of internal defects might be a key solution in fatigue-critical applications of L-PBF parts.

The limited data from costly fatigue testing poses a challenge to train a machine learning model for non-destructive fatigue life prediction for L-PBF specimens. We leveraged the transfer learning technique to develop a novel two-stage multi-modal transfer learning (MMTL) framework. In the first stage, a novel hierarchical graph convolutional network (HGCN) is developed for defect classification with thousands of defects identified in X-ray CT by modeling the impacts of feature combinations on defect types. In the second stage, the MMTL framework adds neural network layers to the pre-trained HGCN for fatigue life prediction by modeling the impacts of feature combinations on stress concentration and fatigue failure. The fatigue testing data at the second stage is much smaller, but MMTL borrows the information of feature combinations at the first stage to model their impacts on stress concentration and fatigue failure.

The data among manufacturers are heterogeneous due to distinct machine specifications. The novel FL framework is developed to handle outstanding data heterogeneity from distributed manufacturing by imposing reasonable assumptions obtained from physics knowledge, which allow the proposed heterogeneity-aware FL model to compress the information of data in a lower-dimensional latent space. Moreover, different federated learning and distributed machine learning techniques, including FedAT, DIGEST, and FedCaSe, are investigated in order to address the resource and data heterogeneity at scale. The proof-of-concept implementations of these techniques demonstrate that the proposed techniques can effectively improve model convergence speed, model accuracy, balance across the training clients, and minimize communication costs.

The findings and results of the project have been disseminated to the research community through publications and conference presentations. The established models, framework, and systems are made open to students, instructors, and researchers. The findings and results have also been incorporated into a class at Auburn to teach undergraduate, graduate and distance students about cutting-edge machine learning and federated learning for distributed manufacturing. Four graduate research assistants from the two institutions have been systematically trained in this interdisciplinary project for their independent research and STEM careers in the future. Several undergraduate students, including a student from an underrepresented group in engineering, were involved in the tasks of the project. Four different outreach activities to high school students have been implemented at Auburn and UVa to introduce advanced technologies and promote further STEM education for high school students. Different tours of the National Center for Additive Manufacturing Excellence at Auburn have been held for many government and private-sector personnel to promote the adoption of L-PBF parts in different industries and improve the collaboration among government, academia and industry on future manufacturing.


Last Modified: 11/12/2024
Modified by: Jia Liu
